head.title: Other Voices: Were Readers Prepared for the Hurricane?

hedline.hl1: Other Voices: Were Readers Prepared for the Hurricane?

block.p: As a native Louisianian who lived in New Orleans for more than 12 years and who now lives in New York City, I believe that a national newspaper needs to be not only more vigilant in its reporting on other parts of the country, but also more comparative.

For example, how did life in the Ninth Ward of New Orleans compare with that in a poor black area of New York City? What makes life better or worse? As a social scientist, I know there are lots of sophisticated statistical ways to compare these things, but a newspaper can strive to put these comparisons into concrete form for readers not familiar with that research.
The writer is a professor of politics at New York University.
